characters: MYSTERIOUS HERMIT OF CALEB COUNTY THROWS A FUNERAL PARTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance and through the trees we see a raging hel fire engulfing a small two story house. It burns and burn Out of nowhere a man bursts through a second story window lands hard and rolls to smother his burning clothes. He crawls away and staggers up and for a moment looks as he might run back into the flames. But the heat is unbearable. He runs toward us then past us through black shadows. We cannot see his face,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glass in a weathered window glitters with early morning s A rock shatters one of the remaining glass panes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rock thrower, TOM ( 10) is hightailing it away from a isolated Appalachian SHACK as the door bangs open, a shot barrel appears, and a chicken comes SQUAWKING out from un the porch! Thinking he's sure to be shot, Tom runs into the old barn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panting in terror, Tom is hunkered down in strips of ligh trying to see through the cracks. There is a loud SNORT a the huge face of some kind of beast suddenly appears at h shoulder. Tom jumps, panicked, just as a SHADOWY FIGURE creeps into barn and levels a glinting shotgun at him! Tom freezes, bends over, and throws up! When Tom looks up, a ray of light reveals the half face o fierce gray bearded man, FELIX BUSH. He is holding out a handkerchief to the boy. Shaking hard, Tom hesitates then takes it and wipes his mouth. Bush pushes open the door and gives Tom a sad look that t boy will never forget before waving him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking back over his shoulder, Tom runs for the road. Tw his BUDDIES are already kicking up dust. BUSH (72) steps into the sun and watches the boy run off a look of muted anger, sadness, and something much deeper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush enters the barn to check on his companion. MULE is o than Bush in mule years and just as gray. He wears an old mule blanket everywhere to keep out the cold. He fidgets nervously from all the excitement. Bush comforts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a boy, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 Bush rips down an old faded sign at the road and posts fresh one:'No Damn Trespassing/Beware of Mule'. Bush chec the road in both directions. All clear for now. 8 Bush splits firewood with powerful cleaving strokes. Mu dozes in the shade. Bush sees a Model-T approach and turn into his road, right past his new sign. He glances at his shotgun leaning against the shack. The Model-T comes to a shaky stop. A MAN climbs out, sees Bush swinging the axe and approaches with trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin', sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard life if you can't read..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon? I'm uh, Reverend Gus Horton, sir, how you doing? Bush stops his swing and turns and stares coldly at Horto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need saving, preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well, Mr. Wiley Starke has passed on, sir. His funeral is tomorrow and I thought you might want to know since..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What got him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just got old, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well.. Bush returns to chopping wood. Feeling awkward, Horton hesitates, starts for his car, st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Starke told me that you and him ran away from home when you were 6 years old. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked him into it. Bush doesn't turn, just keeps chopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.. anyway.. I.. alright.. Horton shrugs, get in his car, and leaves. Bush strikes the log hard and a cleaved piece goes flying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loneliness of the empty cemetery is broken by Wiley Starke's fresh grave. The mounded earth is covered with beautiful flowers and wreathes, a loving send off from hi family and friends. As we pan past the flowers and cards. we realize that the cemetery is not quite empty. Hunkered down nearby, Bush is as still as a gravestone, staring at the last resting place of his old friend. As Bush gets up to leave he stops abruptly and stands fro staring at a pot of YELLOW FLOWERS on a distant grave. No turns and walks quickly away in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain drums hard on the tin roof as Bush, soaked to the bo and shaking with chills, rummages through an old hat box lamp light: Letters, news clippings and keepsakes. He fin what he's looking for: A PICTURE of a BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOM She smiles at us from happier days. Realizing that he is raging with a serious fever, he tries to stand up only to collapse back on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrapped in his quilt and carrying the oil lamp, Bush move slowly toward the barn. But he is so wracked with fever h has to stop. It stuns him that he can't go on. He never thought anything could stop him. Stuck in the rain with t shaking lamp sizzling, he stares into the forever darknes the muscles in his jaw rippling in the pale light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hell..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow he has made it. Sopping wet and shivering, Bush i bad shape and knows it. Mule sees Bush and grunts anxiously as he rises. Bush blindly pours Mule some feed and the poor old thing snatches his first meal in days. Bush tries to think through the fever. He stumbles back t the door and swings it wide open so Mule can get out if B doesn't make it. Satisfied, he comes back and drops hard a pile of hay near Mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always thought you'd go first.. White as cotton, Bush stares into the lamp that is runnin out of oil, the light fading fast to darkness. Thoughts tumble through his mind, troubling him, stirring the dark waters of memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN across the stillness of the foothills to the barn. Th door is still swung wide open. Back from the brink of death, Bush emerges into the blind sunlight. Mule is dozing in his favorite spot. He swings big gray head over at Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, don't look so disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mule watches Bush heave a creaky old wagon out from behin the barn. Mule climbs up on all fours. Bush gets a set of reins and walks toward him. Mule starts to take a stroll, knowing what the reins mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better not. Mule looks back, sees an apple in Bush's hand, and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And coffee when we get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old wheels creak and moan. Bush and Mule ease up Main str with the cart. PEOPLE try to catch a glimpse of the infam recluse. Mule comes to a wearied stop, breathing hard. Bush climbs the cart and walks Mule, ignoring the eyes upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Horton, stoking the wood stove, hears FOOTSTEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy?
But as he turns he sees Bush silently looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Hello.. Horton comes to Bush but Bush ignores him and keeps critically looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, sir? Suddenly BUDDY and KATHRYN ROBINSON (20's) enter from the vestibule with their new BABY. In their own world, and no realizing that there is anyone in the chapel, Kathryn pic some lint from Buddy's jacket. He catches her fingers and kisses them. Bush is transfixed by the loving moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can wait. Buddy and Kathryn see Horton and double-take Bush. Buddy to Horton and he and Kathryn step back into the vestibule give Bush and Horton privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright, have a seat. Bush sits down uneasily in a pew. Horton sits down in the in front of him and twists around to face him. The wintry light from the near window washes over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bout time for me to get low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down to business Bush reaches into his overalls and puts a balled-up wad o MONEY on the pew. Horton's eyes bulge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a funeral. Horton looks up from the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. Buddy peers around from the vestibule, listening, curious hell, until Kathryn pulls him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you? (off Bush's impatient nod) You want to buy a funeral for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not talking right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, yes, I'm sorry. Are you sick sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True, but..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't take care of my bones it won't get done, will it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I see. Well the church can help you get your affairs in order, arrange a service.. Horton glances at the strange wad of money again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A eulogy? I.. don't know. What do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what you'd say right now to my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I uh, I don't know much about you, Mr. Bush. I mean, I've heard stories but..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What stories? Bush leans in and stares into Horton. It feels like everything in the world stops dead. Buddy peeks in again, this time Kathryn peeks too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stories.. (off Bush's intense look) .you know, people talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of stories? Say one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.. my mother used to say that gossip is the devil's radio..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .not that she didn't play that radio at full volume now and then, bless her heart, but.. (back to business) .what matters when you come to the end of your life is that you're ready for the next one. Have you made peace with God, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid. Horton has no idea what Bush means. He looks at the money back at Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.. you can't buy forgiveness, Mr. Bush. It's free. But you do have to ask for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing in this world is free, preacher.

Bush abruptly grabs his money and starts out. His hand ba into the pew and the money FALLS. Buddy stares wild-eyed at the big wad of money then drops back into the vestibule. Bush storms past Buddy, Kathryn and the baby like a hot w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush heads off down the road on his wagon. Horton, Buddy, Kathryn appear at the door and watch him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was, uh, different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard such awful things about him when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother probably told you some of them. Kathryn goes back into the church with Horton who is cooi at the baby. Buddy lingers, staring at Bush, thinking..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush's wagon loaded with bags of feed and supplies, sits front of the Diner. Bush is holding a big tin cup of coffee for Mule who is drinking it and loving it. Tom (the kid who threw the rock) comes from behind the di with a full garbage can to empty into the big trash barre on the back of an old pick-up truck. He sees Bush and freezes. Bush looks up and stares at him. The diner door snaps open and BONNIE (30's), Tom's mother steps out. She sees Tom and Bush staring at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, son? Now Tom is scared to death that Bush is going to tell on Bonnie doesn't like this staring match at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty those cans in your daddy's truck and get back in here. Now. Finally Bush drops his gaze and lets Tom off the hook. Relieved, Tom heaves the can up into the truck. Bonnie hesitates then goes back into the diner just as... .CARL (30s), his sidekick, GARY, and two other MEN come across the street toward the diner. Gary sees Mule slurpi coffee from the big tin cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. A mule drinking coffee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally found somebody that likes Bonnie's coffee. As they move past, they see Bush standing there..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya'll better hush, that's old Bush. Carl eyes him. Gary and the others throw curious glances they head into the diner. Carl stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to you.. Carl picks up a handful of gravel, tosses some over nonchalantly in Bush's direction. Bush ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know about you. You stay out of this diner. There's women and children here and we don't want you around them. Bush stands to mount up, never turning around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better hear me. I see you here again, I'll.. Hey! Hey! Hearing the hollering, Tom looks up from the pick-up. Carl throws a stone, harder this time to get Bush's attention.
But the rock misses Bush and hits Mule, startling him. Ol instincts kick in and he has a VIOLENT FIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.. Carl moves up to try and calm him.. .as Bush tries to ease Mule down the cart hitch grinds a GASH in Mule's hind-quarter. Mule whinnies painfully, slo surrendering. As Carl steps up, Bush yanks the BRAKE HANDLE off the car and hits Carl in the chest. Air explodes from Carl as he gasps with pain. Before he can move, Bush hits him again the same place. Carl wants to hit back but he has no air. Lightning quick, Bush steps back and hits Carl again in t exact same place. Carl falls like a bag of bones. He looks up and sees Bush towering over him with a terrible bottled up darkness in It has all happened so fast it feels like an awful dream Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! Wild with fear, Bonnie and Tom run toward Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!! Get away! Gary, the Worker burst from the diner but see the brake handle in Bush's hand and slow down. Bush comes to himself, sees everyone staring, sees Carl i tears, and now Tom and Bonnie, trying to get him away.. Gary and the others slowly move toward Bush. More patrons step out from the diner. Buddy races up, sees Mule bleeding, and eyes Bush as he g the reins and leads Mule down Main street, still holding brake handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill him! Bonnie shushes him softly as Carl moans in pain. Tom stares after Bush, mirroring his father's hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An EMPTY CASKET, awaits its passenger in a small but serviceable funeral hall. Through the office door, FRANK QUINN sits at his desk, his head completely buried behind paper that he shakes hard every few seconds. His feet are on the desk revealing a pair of lovely burgundy silk sock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's hand slips the flask next to his coffee cup into drawer when he HEARS the front door open. But his face remains hidden as Buddy enters. Buddy is troubled by the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank? (off Frank's grunt) There was a fight. It was..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .let me guess. Hmm. Carl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah but this time it was with that old man Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the old man did the beating. Never seen anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Social event of the year and I missed it. Frank lowers the paper so just his eyes appear. He has no southern accent and doesn't look small town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read the paper today? (off Buddy's no) Something strange is happening in the world right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are dying in bunches. (off Buddy's look) Everywhere. But here. He puts the paper down and studies his socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what the odds are of a funeral home going broke? I mean you have a business everybody on earth needs, you can't make that work, it's got to be you right? And yet.. I don't know.. what do you do when people won't die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onethingabout Chicago, people knowhowto die; they drown, get runover,shot, whatever it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get it done down here, we're just not in a hurry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's them or us. Frank sighs and stares forlornly out at a casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might know someone who is looking for a funeral. Frank's eyes crawl over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Quinn Funeral Home Packard Hearse makes it way down t road. Frank drives as Buddy searches ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much did he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was all wadded up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooo, hermit money. That's good. Buddy sees Bush's signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is..

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. FRANK'S CAR/FRONTAGE ROAD
dialogues.text: They stop at Bush's sign: 'No Damn Trespassing." Frank squints up at the old shack and doesn't like what he sees all. Buddy opens his door but Frank doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been wanting a shot at sales..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As of right now, you're on commission. (off Buddy's look) Remember; foot in the door, establish trust, and drop the hammer. Buddy hesitates, crawls out, and eyes the shack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd feel better if you'd go too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt but if you don't do this by yourself, you won't know if you're any good. And you'll never be any good if you don't know you are. Go get him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Buddy uneasily approaches the shack, he feels the beautiful stillness and mystery of the place. He KNOCKS timidly on the door, pressing an ear to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Nothing. He shoots a look back to the hearse - miles away and knocks a little louder. Nothing. He inches to the win and peeks in one of the remaining glass panes then starts slide away.. CLICK. Buddy spins and discovers Bush standing on the ground beh him, his shotgun barrel pointed between Buddy's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to see in my house, do you? BOOM! Bush blows away several windowpanes and re-aims at Buddy's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it look? Buddy closes his eyes, his last words are for his wife..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Katie.. It makes Bush peek out from behind the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You was at the church with your wife and baby. Buddy opens his eyes and can't believe he is still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? They stand there while Buddy thinks..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I heard.. you wanted a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. I work at uh.. I work at.. (tries to think of it) .Quinn Funeral Home. I thought I could help you. Bush glances at his blown out window: 'Damn'. He lowers h gun, walks up onto the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like rabbit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Bush goes inside. Buddy looks desperately back at the hearse but can't see Frank. He doesn't know whether to run for it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shack is spare as a monk's chamber but has wonderful MADE FURNITURE in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. There is only chair at the table so Buddy dumps the glass a small stool under the window and sits down low. The won of not being dead makes him look at everything with new e On a window sill he sees a beautiful little CARVED MULE emerging from a block of wood.
Bush is at the stove tending to a iron skillet of rabbit pieces covered with bacon and white gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's how you put things together, see? Some things go, some things never will. Indians said that everything spoke to them. That's how they made medicine and knew what to eat. Things talked to them clear as we talk. You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I.. I don't know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't listen you won't hear nothing. Bush puts the big skillet on the table and sits down. Buddy is so low he can look under the table and sees how table legs run right into the top without screws or nails

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make this furniture, sir? Never seen any like it. Can't even tell what's holding it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic. Buddy looks up. Bush is dead serious. The word lingers. Finally..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Well. Sir, if you do want to plan for a funeral service, which I hope will be a long long time away, we'd treat you with respect and offer a good..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd everybody say about what happened in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That crazy old son of a bitch tried to beat a man to death for no reason? That it?
Buddy is caught off guard by Bush's lucid candor and find himself automatically responding differently to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two sides to every story. As Bush puts some rabbit on Buddy's old yellowed plate..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People say that. But they don't mean it. They think what they think and they don't want to know anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, but I think people are so scared of what they don't know that they make things up to feel better about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like life after dying. Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that part's true, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't think we know the actual truth about much of anything. I know I don't. I'm just guessing most of the time. Bush gives Buddy a closer look and motions for him to try rabbit. Fearing the worst, Buddy bends into the steam, ta a cautious bites and mutters with shocked surprise..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, that's good..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys been coming out here to throw rocks through my window for 20-30 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya'll know lots of stories about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I guess, but..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not. Bush eases forward, his eyes slit. The old Bush is back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rather you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled/leans back) Well. When I was kid I heard you killed some men in a fist fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all? Bush leans back stone-faced. In the silence, Buddy looks over again at the wondrous carving of the mule on the window sill, at the big ears a long face that are being born from the rough block. It ma him smile. But when he glances back, Bush is staring a ho through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy Robinson, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if I need you -- I know where you are. It sounds almost like a threat. It shorts Buddy out. He s eating and realizes that Bush has taken another turn and he's been dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy heads to the hearse, glancing back over his shoulde As he recalls his encounter, he stops, looking back at th shack. The old legend has gotten deep under his skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning sun breaks over the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush is on the porch, straining boiled herbs, grass, and into a jar. There is something not right with him and he knows it. While the medicine cools he looks out across th mountain and draws a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well crafted live-in home doubling as a funeral parlor. sign, 'QUINN FUNERAL HOME', hangs from the porch.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh yes Ma'am, I do respect your wishes but you see..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is looking a little hung over. Buddy walks in. Fran points at the phone and rolls his blood shot eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .state law requires.. No ma'am, we can't bury him under the house.. There is a loud KNOCK at the door. Buddy goes to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy swings the door open. Bush is standing there. Buddy leans back unconsciously, not knowing what to expect.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Well just for argument's sake, Ma'am, how would we get the casket under the house? No casket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to come in, sir?
Bush stares suspiciously into the room then back at Buddy

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: But you have to have a container of some kind, Ma'am for decency and uh, sanitation. Bush enters the Funeral Home. As Buddy starts to close th door, Bush catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is still on the phone and pouring himself a drink f the flask into his coffee cup in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am, but there's lots of natural things that aren't decent. (listens, eyes widen) He did what?! Good God. No, Ma'am, I didn't know that about your husband. Well, yeah now I understand why you want him under the house but still.. The phone goes dead. FRANK sighs as Bush walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Quinn, Mr. Bush. Frank takes a quick swallow from his cup to fortify himse then jumps up, smiling, and goes to Bush with his hand ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, come in, pleasure. Coffee? As Bush shakes Frank's hand, he stares into him, taking everything in, his bloodshot eyes, the wrinkled shirt ben his suit, his breath. Frank feels downright naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You from anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little bit of everywhere, I guess. Get him a chair, Buddy! Buddy stands behind the waiting chair.

Bush scrapes up a different chair. Frank goes behind the desk. Buddy pulls up a chair. Bush reaches into his coat and pulls out the wad of hermi money and lays it on the desk. Frank does something phenomenal. He ignores the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we help you, sir? Bush gives Buddy a look, then looks back at Frank who steadfastly refuses to look at the ball of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm after a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, are you in luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Buddy stand with Bush in a room dedicated to sa Three caskets are lined up for display. All tanks. Bush steps up to a cheap cloth covered box, bangs it with knuckles, and scowls. Frank points to a wooden casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solid pecan, steel handles.. Bush eyes it, repulsed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bush is an amazing carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the box. What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you want, flowers..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burial plot..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funeral party. Stumped for once in his life, Frank looks at Buddy. Then years of honed instincts surge back to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they come back into the office..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I want to be there. Frank goes behind his desk. Buddy and Bush start to sit..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be, I guarantee it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to be at your funeral.. party.. alive? (off Bush's nod) But.. it's not a funeral if you're not, you know, deceased..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on now, it's a detail, we can look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty big detail.
Frank cuts Buddy a look then smiles at Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'd like to have a funeral party while you're alive so you can go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Buddy is lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, get some paper. We need to make of list of who Mr. Bush wants to invite.. As Buddy starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. Buddy sits right down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want everybody to come who's got a story to tell about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That probably covers 4 counties.. Bush shoots him a look. Frank shoots him a look. Buddy th about how great an outdoor life would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I want 4 counties worth of people at the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, the thing is, how would you get people to come and tell stories about you that I'm guessing might get them, you know.. shot? Bush scoops up the ball of money and heads out. Now all F can see is the money, leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, you go ahead, don't worry about it, we'll think of something. A couple of ideas just came to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bush starts out the open door, he nearly bumps into Buddy's wife, Kathryn, and MATTIE DARROW. Mattie is carry Kathryn and Buddy's baby boy. Frank sees Mattie and flicks his hair back nervously and quickly brushes his teeth with his finger as.. .Bush gives Mattie a glance and tries to be invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix?! Feigning deafness, Bush walks on. Sensing something, Kath takes the baby so Mattie can go after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix! Say hello to me! Frank, eyes wide with surprise, mouths, "Felix?". Bush's shoulder hunch then fall as he turns. He looks int her, taking everything in. When he speaks his eyes and vo are soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mattie. Buddy comes out, surprised to see Mattie and Bush togethe Frank walks up behind him and scowls. Kathryn steers them back inside to give Mattie privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heard you moved off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been back a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you always did. He abruptly rips himself away and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy and Frank are peeking out the window. They see Matt standing alone as Bush walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would she know him?

dialogues.speaker: KATHRYN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: It's none of our business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? We got to know. Kathryn shakes her head and goes back outside. FRANK has another look at Mattie then lets the curtain fall back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the size of that thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, what? Goddamn ball of money! He wants a party with pink balloons on his ears, we're gonna give it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sold 26 of the ugliest cars ever made one December, in Chicago, with wind blowing so hard up my ass I was farting snow flakes in July so don't tell me we can't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last "but" I want to hear out of you. You're a salesman now, sell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out again) She called him Felix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathryn rocks the baby in a carriage. Mattie is beside he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand years ago he was the most interesting man I'd ever met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was. And I don't mean just the way he looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, listen, he was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people are just laid out nice and simple, you know? You always know what they're thinking and where you are with them. But he was this.. big old cave that went deeper and deeper. You'd never get to the end of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord, you had a crush on him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the girls did. I know he's something wild that crawls out of the hills once in a while and gets into trouble now but there's still nobody like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush comes out of the barn. Frank and Buddy are there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a plan. All we need is a little bit of your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing it is better than hearing about it. Bush looks at the hearse, back at Buddy and Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is it gonna cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say anything about money? (touches his own chest) I didn't say anything about money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can't get you what you want you don't owe us anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Buddy, and Bush ride in the front seat of the hear They are together but in very different worlds. They don' even look at each other when they talk. Buddy is lost in serious thought. Frank is preoccupied about the deal and driving too fast. Bush is scrunched up to the door. He is going much faster than he is used to going. He kinda likes it and kinda doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It moves, don't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancy car for the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't buy it for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of nowhere) We say that funerals are "For the Living" but we forget what that means sometimes, I guess. (to Bush but almost to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking about your funeral party before I went to sleep last night and I think I understand it a little now. When I was a kid, my folks where killed in a bad car wreck and the people at the funeral home... they did the impossible as far as I was concerned. I don't know what I would've done without them. And I remember wishing that my mother and daddy were there to see how beautiful they made everything. Frank is hearing this for the first time and is shocked. glances softly at Buddy then looks out the side window at world rushing by too fast. All at once he gives in to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearse pulls up on main street. Frank, Buddy, and Bus get out and head toward Feldman's Clothing Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Buddy enter the store and find MR. FELDMAN and PHOTOGRAPHER setting up a large camera and backdrop. As t turn to show Bush what is happening they see him go by th window outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's he going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barber's drape falls over BUSH who is seated in a chair Frank and Buddy rush in. The barber, an anxious Mr. Tollerude, pumps Bush's chair upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't do that yet. Bush gives him the hairy eyeball then speaks to Mr. Tollerude, a clear threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bush, you can get all the hairs cut you want after we take your picture, I'll pay for it. Mr. Tollerude doesn't know whether to cut or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you want my picture made?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're trying to tell you. We're gonna run an ad in some papers about your party and put up posters of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want me to look like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's how people recognize you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want as many people to come as possible so..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So a crazy old nutter draws more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basically. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever say what you mean? Bush rips the bib off as Tollerude whooshes him to the fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush is seated in front of a backdrop painted with a brid a swan, and a pond. The Photographer is trying to tidy up Bush without offending him. As he walks back to camera, B roughs himself up and looks truly wild. Buddy snickers. When the Photographer gets back to the camera, he cocks his head, what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it. (leans in to Buddy) I'd go see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Tollerude, nervous as hell, brings Bush up from his reclining position and turns the chair to the mirror. Bush studies his well trimmed hair and beard for a moment It's impossible to tell what his thoughts are as he looks into his own eyes. Buddy and Frank are in the mirror too, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. You look pretty good.. Bush suddenly gets up and nods at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's paying. As Bush blows out the door, Mr. Tollerude leans against t chair with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush stands in front of a full length mirror. He has on a decent black suit, pinned to be hemmed, and a plain white shirt, open at the collar. It is a startling change. But still can't tell what he is thinking. Buddy is staring at him with honest disbelief. Frank is quietly trying to get Mr. Feldman to lower the p for the suit. He looks over and double-takes Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch, it's almost worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the Devil won't either. Might work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, normally people don't wear shoes in a casket so.. (off Bush's scowl) .what are you, about a 10D?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy stands beside Frank who is still trying to get a de on the clothes. Bush walks up with two pairs of pants and new shirts, puts them on the counter, gives Frank a hard look, and walks away. Frank looks down at the clothes, ov at Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty optimistic taking a change of clothes to the grave. (calls over his shoulder) How you set for underwear?

dialogues.speaker: BUSH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't wear none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One question too many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is back in the hearse. Something is eating at Fr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be nosey but uh.. how do you know Mattie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a peach. Frank and Buddy cut Bush a look. He looks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a go. Frank nearly drives off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late night Poker. Cigarette smoke drifts into the air. Frank, Carl, Rev. Horton, Mattie, and RAY, a banker, are the table. Ray has the untouchable presence of someone privileged which appears to be driving Frank up a tree tonight. Horton gathers up his winnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Lord loves a cheerful giver.."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please.. you think the Lord's taking sides in a poker game in a funeral home? Horton shrugs and points to the divine evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If He is, the Divine's cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't agree with me Ray, it makes me doubt myself.
Ray sighs and studies his perfectly cut nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have turned down your loan if you were my own dear mother, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made my point and don't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, would you two stop it! You're worse than two old women.. Ray shrugs, sweetly blase. Frank tries to rein in his tem for her. The loss of the hand is especially hard on Carl has only a couple of dollars left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing with that old bastard in town today, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Buying him clothes, getting him a haircut..on credit. Frank shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Took out ads in a bunch of papers too, something about a party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I love small towns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hermit, what's his name..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a knowing look at Mattie) "Felix" Bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're giving him a party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A funeral party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you're drinking is not being good to you at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is a funeral party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, the man wants to be at his own funeral. What can I say? I'd like to be at my funeral so I could tell my ex-wife to kiss my..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think she'd show up for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, Dear, vultures are constitutionally unable to ignore the dead. Mattie grins which delights Frank, no end. Horton stops counting his money and stares at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that big wad of money of his you're after. There is a crack in Ray's disinterest that he tries to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What money is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix has money? Everyone is looking at Frank but he shuffles the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came to see me, wanting a funeral, had a big old greasy ball of money. Talked like he thought he could buy his way to heaven with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much has he got? Maybe he can. Hearing that Bush wants or needs a real funeral Mattie is suddenly truly concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he sick, Gus? Horton shrugs. Frank notes the concern and doesn't like i Carl coughs and his ribs make him break out into a sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you one damn thing, ain't nobody gonna go to a funeral for that son of a bitch. Mattie gives Carl a look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Language..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might. He's inviting everyone who has a story about him to come. You could tell about him kicking your ass, Carl. Carl looks at Frank as if he wants to cold cock him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old man is going to ride the Weird Train right into the ground, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you like to know what everybody says about you behind your back, Ray? (off his look) Yeah, probably not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already know way more about people than I need to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's play some cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for God's sake, face it Frank, you're broke. This is not about cards. It's a declaration meant to embarrass Frank in front of everyone. Frank feels their e on him as he starts to pull off his watch. Ray waves it o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. I've won that 4 times already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's who has it last that counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what you want but if there hadn't been anybody there the other day he would've killed me. And I guarantee you it wouldn't have been his first time. It sounds true and everyone is quiet except Mattie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody knows you started it. (off his glare) Don't look at me like that. I remember when you were born. You were the sweetest little boy. What is wrong with you? Momentarily shamed, Carl's face softens and we can see a better man there. He struggles to hold on to it but..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a mistake. But there's a line.. and he crossed it.. and everybody knows that too. Ya'll go on and have a party with the devil for his money but I'll dance on his grave someday. Carl snatches his few dollars up and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kind of hate to admit it when it comes to Carl but he's got a point. You don't know what Bush is doing. What if he just wants to get everybody in one place so he can turn his shotgun on them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked in his eyes. The truth is nobody knows what he's capable of. Maybe even he doesn't know. She looks into him. Frank starts to deal the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and lay your watch down, Frank. But I am going to keep it this time, alright, on principle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an idea. Let's try something different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cards in your sock? Leave'em there. Everyone freezes. Ray shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to pull now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think you're that good that nobody sees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cheat at everything you do. Even at the bank, you loan people just enough to get'em deeper in so you can foreclose on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a pathetic man. And a goddamn..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I? Then stand up and roll down your socks. (a deep dark look) Stand up or I'll stand you up. Ray looks around the table and suddenly realizes that he irreversibly exposed and alone. The sound of Frank's chai scraping the floor makes him jerk up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, trying to find his old confident rhythm and failing. Everyone sits in uneasy silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horton waves and walks out, leaving the door open. Frank walks Mattie to the door, helping with her coat, trying t work up his nerve to say.. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk you home. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. FRANK (HURT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure? (off her firm nod) You're not going to play anymore, are you? MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Thank you for inviting me though. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about the..we don't always fight, okay, we do, but he's had that coming for.. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that. I just..(trails off) FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came because you don't know what to do with yourself. (off her look) I slept on the same side of the bed my whole life, right? But after my wife left me, I switched sides, just like that, and never been able to go back. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When someone you love is gone, you can pour everything, even a lifetime of things into the place where they were but it's still always empty.
He sees that her thoughts are not with him at all but a million miles away. She hardly glances up when she says.. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night. He stares after her, wishing that she could see him the w he sees her. 59 OMIT 59

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim lamp light glows. We see Bush sitting on the edge of bed wiping the sweat from his face with a sheet. He looks at the picture of the beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy sits in the dark, rocking his son who is asleep. A small lamp casts a shadow across them. Kathryn comes in. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear him wake up. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't. KATHRYN (KNEELING DOWN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's all right, hon. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you don't know how quick it can change. She gently kisses his arm and the baby's head. Buddy look her, haunted by the very possibility of their absence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie is standing on the sidewalk at Feldman's store wit her coat collar pulled up against the cold, giving someon can't see a bemused affectionate scolding.. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord. Have you completely lost your mind? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 40A.
dialogues.text: MATTIE (cont`d) Straighten up for heaven's sake before somebody throws a net over you!  But she smiles in spite of herself, glances around to see anyone was watching and moves discretely on. As she does see that she was talking to a striking WANTED POSTER of a wild man sitting in front of a pond, a swan, and a bridge The text reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny PLACE, cramped with radio gear. Buddy and Frank peer through a glass window into a small control booth.(We will cut back and forth between the gla Buddy is having misgivings about being here. But Frank gi the thumbs up to the young WCGM ANNOUNCER in the booth, a hopeful kid with a smooth voice and dreams of the big-tim The Announcer hands Bush a set of headphones. Bush is wea his new clothes and truly looks like a different man. Bush is puzzled by the headset. The kid takes it and clam it onto Bush's head. He starts to yank them off then hear song playing inside his head and loves it. But now the announcer cuts the record off and Bush scowls. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends, we have a treat for you today on WCGM. Our special guest is going to tell us about an event that everyone is talking about. And here he is, Mr. Felix Bush, the mysterious hermit of Caleb County! How are you today, sir? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Bush is surprised by the sound of his own voice. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell us, sir, exactly how did you come up with the idea of having a funeral party before you die? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed it.
ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I make that up? Two seconds of dead air as the announcer finds his feet. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Now I have to say that you don't look quite like you do on the posters. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got pruned. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're a bit of a local legend, sir. I was a little nervous about our interview. I've heard some pretty wild stories.. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what? ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well uh, just.. from what I understand, you want everyone who has a story about you to come and tell it. Is that right? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come and tell yours. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now how long have you been living out there by yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie is cutting the stems of some lovely yellow flowers arranging them in a vase.

dialogues.speaker: BUSH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: 40 some years.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: 40 years with nobody to talk to?

dialogues.speaker: BUSH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: First 38 are the hardest.
Mattie grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would you do that, Mr. Bush, shut yourself off like that? Frank isn't happy with this but Buddy wants to hear. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to the funeral and maybe you'll find out. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard it here on WCGM, folks, find out the answer to the mystery February 16.. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more thing, boy. FRANK and Buddy tense. What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie tenses at the sound in Bush's voice.

dialogues.speaker: BUSH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Gonna be a drawing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What kind of drawing, sir? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You buy a ticket for $5.00 The day of the funeral we draw names. Then when I die, the winner gets my place, 300 acres of timber that hasn't been touched in 40 years. Mattie accidentally cuts a bloom off of a flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead air. The kid, Frank, and Buddy are all staring at Bu ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For 5 dollars?
BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send it to the Quinn Funeral Home. Frank's eyes light up like fiery pinwheels and he almost yelps! Buddy looks oddly perplexed and sad. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard him! If you want a chance to win 300 acres of virgin timber worth thousands and thousands of dollars, send 5 dollars along with your name and address to.. (off Frank waving and pointing to himself) Frank Quinn at Quinn Funeral Home. As the Announcer begins a song, Bush moves his head in ti with the music. Frank and Buddy rush into the control boo FRANK (TO BUSH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could almost kiss you on the mouth! ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take a ticket. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're betting on a man dying.. ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it like.. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's his idea! They look at Bush who has taken off the headset and looki at it like he wants to take it home. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what you want, right? BUSH (TO BUDDY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy a ticket, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie puts the vase of flowers on table with a group of family photographs. The picture beside the vase is the SA PHOTOGRAPH of the beautiful woman that Bush has. Is it Mattie? It looks a little like her.
INSERT PHOTO: The BEAUTIFUL YOUNG WOMAN stares at us as w PULL BACK TO REVEAL that we are now looking at the identi photo tacked to Bush's wall. 69 OMIT 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush starts out of the barn, draws back, and peeks throug the wall boards: A FIGURE approaches. He jerks.. REVEAL Mattie walking BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie? MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix? Mattie enters, straining to see into the barn. Her eyes adjust to find him standing near Mule. She is startled an pleased by his new do. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you. I wondered if you were still under that beard. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't nowhere else to go. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you on the radio. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've gotten downright chatty. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon so. MATTIE (GLANCING AROUND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is nice. I drove by a few times after I got back but.. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see it?
MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first stop on the tour is a small fenced grave site n the shack. Three grave markers with names carved into the KEEPER, CHARLIE, MAUDE. Bush is squatting down staring at the markers. Mattie sta close beside him. Since his attention is elsewhere she lo at him in an unguarded way. Her mind is full of questions old and new. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always know where you stand with a dog. Want to lay here with them someday if they'll have me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie and Bush walks side by side through the last of th glimmering light and shadows beneath the trees. It is a chilly and Mattie's cheeks are flushed. She is enchanted the place. Bush tries to hide how winded he is.. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really is beautiful. Probably looked like this everywhere a hundred years ago. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave things alone, they know what to do. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ma'am. I don't know what to do about anything much. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been alone a long time. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people are more suited to it than others, I reckon.

dialogues.speaker: 46A.
dialogues.text: MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny cause I never thought that it'd suit you. I knew you wouldn't be like anybody else but.. no one to talk to, no one to.. be with.. never. He looks into her then looks away at something. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you sleeping these days, girl? MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I what?
BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sleep good? MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not lately. How'd you know? He veers off the path and pulls up a plant and brings it to her. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chamomile, it's good when the  nights get long. Helps you nod off. She takes it and smiles up at him. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to go on a ways?  MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you stay for supper?  MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be any trouble.  BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A supper guest every 30-40 years is  not much trouble, Girl.  MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then.  He holds out his arm.  BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better stay close, some big old  wild cats been eating my chickens..  She looks around and takes his arm.  BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .or maybe it was me..  She snorts and slaps his arm but doesn't let go..  73 OMITTED 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the dark room together. Bush lights a lantern, gets a chair from a corner and holds it out for her. She and watches him check a cast iron pot on the warm stove a put a log on the fire. She notices the beautiful table. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always were good with your hands. He puts a glass of tea in front of her and sits down. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still play the piano? MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach a few girls. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a good feeling when you played. Remember that time you was playing and the lamp burned out? And you went right on in the dark? I hear that song sometimes at night. She shrugs shyly and sips the tea. Seconds tick by. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure is quiet out here. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cocks his head) What? MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it's.. (stops/gets the joke) I tried to write you at times but I didn't know what to say. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I heard you married. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a Doctor; a real good man. We lived in St. Louis for awhile. He died unexpectedly about a year ago. I came back here because.. I have no idea why. (sips tea/thinks) (MORE)     49 MATTIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The list of people who are gone is getting longer and longer and sometimes I feel like all I'm doing is waiting for my name to come up. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a tender heart, always did. She gives him a curious look. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't wait for anything, Mattie. Close your eyes, hold your breath.. stay in one spot your whole life, but you're still moving, like the world's moving under you. There's no waiting. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's no getting over some things either, is there? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon not, Little Bit. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Bit?! Oh my God, nobody's called me that in.. But suddenly she is lifted from the chair as if by strong ropes. She stares at the wall as she walks toward Bush's Bush is stricken and white. He would stop her if he could it is too late. She walks right up to the picture at the edge of the lamp light and stares into it as if it is a mirage that will disappear if she blinks. Finally she whirls and looks at him, her face a tortured mask. A strangled sob escapes her. He gets up and stands there staring at the floor. Suddenly she is moving toward him and then past him and o the door. Her shadow merges with the darkness. Bush stand with his head down, staring into oblivion. 75 OMIT 75
76 OMITTED 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy comes in frowning and lugging a heavy mail sack. Wh the hell? He looks up and sees more sacks dumped on the d Frank is grinning and ripping open envelopes from the sac and each one has 5 dollars in it! Buddy looks down and se even more mail sacks on the floor! FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, kid! BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! But, but it's not our money. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah, no, but some of it's gonna be! We're putting this thing on! Frank rips open two more envelopes and dollar bills rain to the floor. He's beside himself. Buddy eyes him warily. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should be here. I'm gonna go get him. They lock eyes. Frank finally tosses him the hearse keys. 79 OMITTED 79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy, Frank, and Bush are staring reverently at the mone stacked across the desk and the full paper sacks all arou the desk. Bush eyes Buddy who is still quiet.
FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly how much your land's worth but looks to me like you could get maybe 10 times that or more. I don't know what to do with it. I mean it's yours to do with what you want but I'm getting a little nervous about it. Never thought I'd see enough money to make me nervous. We should probably talk about the price for everything, the clothes, the ads, the food and drink for the party, the music.. our fee for everything, we'll be fair about that, I'm not worried about it. Bush is looking at Buddy who is looking across the room. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, boy? Buddy jerks, looks at Frank, at Bush. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money makes people do funny things. Frank scowls. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should probably put it in the bank, sir. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Ray is not.. (off Bush's look) I mean, if it was my money I'd put it in a bank out of town so everyone didn't know my business. This bank here, you can't trust, that's all I'm saying. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I trust you? FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every name, every dollar, is right there! BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not what I asked.
FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done a hell of a job for you. I don't see why.. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bush, I didn't mean to imply.. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've sold horses, cars, houses, hell, pocket watches pinned to the inside of my coat. I'm not ashamed of it. I don't rob banks, don't cheat at cards, and I sleep all right the nights I sleep. What was the question..? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They goddamn.. He nods at the money and suddenly becomes the "other" Bus BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take out for the expenses you've already had and give me the receipts. As the bills come in for things, give them to me and I'll pay them. Put this money in a box and the boy and I'll take it someplace in the morning. Whatever new comes in, keep it in the bottom of one of them ugly caskets in there 'till I come get it. After the party, name a fair price for what you've done and we'll settle up. (WALKING OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be at the car. After he's gone, Frank and Buddy stare at each other. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it just me or is he extremely fucking articulate when he wants to be? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who's selling who what anymore.
FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not clear, is it? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only that but something feels really wrong. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. I told you that you were working on commission.. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but.. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whatever our end of this is, you get a piece. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece? FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half. It could help set you up, Buddy. So whatever feels wrong is gonna feel right pretty damn quick,okay? We just have to close it out. From here on, watch me, do what I do, and we'll be fine. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But.. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants you to go with him to take this money somewhere which means that it's you he trusts. And that's fine because I trust you too. Just don't trust him, okay? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lost again. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, that funny feeling you have.. I have it too. And it's not funny. So go along, be friendly, but that's it. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a euphoria that comes with closing a deal, Buddy, and the bigger the deal, the higher you get. It's better than anything. (MORE)     54 FRANK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the critical time is just before it closes. It's like a witching hour and everything tries to come apart. We're not going to let that happen. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go. (as Buddy starts out) You know.. I always wondered why you wanted to work here. I thought you could do a lot better. (off Buddy's look back) I didn't know about your folks, I'm really sorry. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He goes on. Frank turns and flips through a large stack of bills, hungrily entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy's son is crying his heart out. Kathryn comes in unbuttoning her blouse, picks him up, sits down, slips he blouse off her shoulder, brings the boy to her breast and voila, his sorrow miraculously vanishes. Buddy appears in the doorway, his eyes soft with love. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have a crying fit coming on too. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling a little weepy. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys.. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leans against door frame) I can maybe do something really good for us, Katy.
KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already have. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, money wise. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Mr. Bush? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm getting half of whatever we make off of him. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why aren't you happy about it? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know I wasn't. (off her look) I was happy for a minute. And then the whole thing of making a carnival out of a person's death, I don't know if it's right. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it what he wants? BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it is. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not responsible for what other people do, Buddy, just you. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. You're always right. KATHRYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I am when I'm half naked. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very determined little GIRL is working her way through song on the piano that is unrecognizable in this form, ev to her. Mattie sits just behind the girl with tears in her eyes, really listening. On the table beside the piano is a stac picture albums and old yellowed newspaper articles.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT BUSH'S SHACK/HEARSE
dialogues.text: Sitting in the hearse outside of Bush's shack, Buddy watc Bush get in the car with his shotgun. There is a big wood box of money on the seat between them. Bush props his sho against it. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to, sir? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting the hearse) How far? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till I say, son. Buddy gives him an uneasy look and pulls off down the tre lined path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearse slips around the narrow road that cuts through miles of farm land lying fallow in the winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy looks out at the highway. He is driving slow. Bush leaning against the money, thinking. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much further now? Bush waves him on. Buddy scowls then decides to get serio about this. He presses on the accelerator and the hearse takes off down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is hopelessly lost in a sea of envelopes. The phone ringing off the hook, there are full sacks around him, an some Reporter is trying to take a picture through the fro window. Frank scowls and lowers the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is at Mattie's door entranced by the troubled but beautiful piano music coming from inside. It stops abrupt when he knocks. In seconds, Mattie appears. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mattie. He looks almost boyish and bashful as he drinks her in. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that you? It was really.. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a surprise. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sorry. He stands, loving the view, forgetting why he is here. She waits it out as long as she can, not sure how she fee about this adoring look. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there something you..? FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.. Help! MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up to my ears with this funeral and I thought, you know, we haven't had time to talk much lately so maybe you'd like to come over and rip open envelopes with me and MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I have lessons all afternoon. I have to get back in. FRANK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, I just.. MATTIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. She slips back inside. Frank stares at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mattie leans against the door with her eyes closed. There no student at the piano. 89 OMITTED 89/90 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearse is parked in front of a beautiful white board church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Bush and Buddy. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say nothing. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To who? BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can say "hi". Bush gets out. Buddy sighs, mimes "Hi" and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy quietly creeps in through the front door, looks bac over his shoulder, scowls, and enters the church. 93 He stops and looks around, awed by the beautifully ser sanctuary. Now he sees a tall BLACK MAN (70) come out of an office d behind the pulpit, walk up the aisle, glancing out the wi at the driveway, and then at Buddy. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Buddy is out of words that he is allowed to say. He glanc at the door but Bush is not coming in.
BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Charlie holds out his hand, Buddy shakes it. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're in the right place? Not expecting a funeral. Suddenly Bush steps into the church. Charlie squints over then stares at Bush with utter disbelief. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix?! BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charlie. They shake hands, then hug. Buddy is blown away that Bush would hug anyone. Bush looks up at the church rafters. BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still standing. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Charlie give Bush a look then holds out his hand to Buddy again. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Charlie Jackson. BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! BUSH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Buddy Robinson, he don't talk much. CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone better talk. A ghost pulls up in the driveway in a hearse, you expect a little bit of a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bush, Buddy and Charlie, sit in pews near a lovely altar.
CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
